intro: Lagochilopsis hirtus, commonly known as the hairy-lipped larkspur, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the family Ranunculaceae and is characterized by its showy, blue or purple flowers that bloom in late spring. The plant has hairy stems and leaves, which contribute to its common name. It thrives in rocky or gravelly soils and is often found in alpine or subalpine habitats. Due to its ornamental value, it is sometimes cultivated in gardens, though it can be toxic to livestock.
